arm_group.description: Patients who received a nasojejunal catheter

brief_summary.textblock:
Curative treatment of upper gastrointestinal tract neoplasms is complex and associated with
      high morbidity and mortality. In general, the patients are already malnourished, and early
      postoperative enteral nutrition is recommended. However, there is no consensus concerning
      the best enteral access route in these cases.

clinical_study.brief_title: Randomized Clinical Trial: Nasoenteric Catheter or Jejunostomy

detailed_description.textblock:
A prospective randomized trial  with patients undergoing esophagectomy, total gastrectomy or
      pancreaticoduodenectomy to asses the outcomes of either jejunostomy placement or catheter
      placement

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  age over 18,

          -  gastrointestinal resections

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  age under 18,

          -  no gastrointestinal procedure

study_pop.textblock: Patients with gastrointestinal disorders undergoing major abdominal operations

clinical_study.keyword: Gastrointestinal surgery, complications, length of hospital stay, mortality
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized Clinical Trial: Nasoenteric Catheter or Jejunostomy as a Route For Nutrition After Major Upper Gastrointestinal Operations

overall_official.last_name: Maria Isabel TD Correia, MD, PhD

oversight_info.authority: Brazil: National Committee of Ethics in Research

primary_outcome.description: Follow up patients after undergoing operation up to 30 days

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Length of hospital stay in both groups

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Prospective
